All_Comments: I have worked for more than 10 years in academia as a research assistant in many different institutes, even in different countries, and I see the same pretty much everywhere: PhD students are not capable or learning time management surrounding PhD life, mainly because most of them lack a clear guidance from their supervisor. And more often than I care to admit, I have seen PhD students being "dropped" (active support stops) by their supervisor if he/she believes the project is not leading to a high impact publication. This causes them to either try to manage on their own, or they pull on other scientists, e.g post doc graduates. At the same time, they then get criticised by their supervisor for the work they are doing. I also often hear students not feeling comfortable bringing up these issues with their supervisor or really having anyone to go to with it. For instance a PhD office or similar with people dedicated to help students with such issues. In addition to this, there is this unwritten rule that when you do a PhD you should not have a life outside this. It is expected you work non stop, and get paid nothing for as many years as possible. My personal opinion is that mental health is just something that is not a "hot topic" in academia. It may be officially but in the daily life in the institutions, the individual groups, amongst colleagues it is not something that is talked about, and if you do bring it up it is something people don't want to touch. There is still a very old fashioned way of thinking when it comes to this. And this is not only with mental health. The same is the case for sexual harassment, gender equality etc. Especially the higher up you get in the 'hierarchy'. So if you do go to your supervisor or anyone else who is actually in a situation where they can help you, because they have the 'power' to do so, you are less likely to actually get that help or just a level of understanding from your superiors. This causes you to kind of get defeated every time you ask for help/advice, so eventually you stop asking, and that is usually when things then start to spiral out of control. I know in my institution there is the option to get counselling, but I have no clue who can get this - if it is only students - or how to access it. It is not something that is really advertised - you just sort of hear about it. In addition, this person is placed in a different campus for us, so we would need a 50 minutes train ride to get there (and then back again).

More importantly, for a person struggling (also to integrate and socialise) an institute specific professional might be easier to access as the first step to seeking help. Workshops and talks about these issues would also increase awareness and decrease the stigma associated with seeking help. Just like we have first aid experts at institutes to deal with physical conditions we should consider having therapists to deal with mental conditions. This survey marks the start of an important initiative to understand and find better solutions to a prevelant problem in research/academia. I hope this provides a strong voice to the community to push this dialogue forward.

I have worked in several different institutions and supported staff and students who have had mild to severe mental health issues. The level of understanding of mental health issues between groups, and between institutions, has been extremely unpredictable. In some cases I have had a group leader tell me not to "waste time" talking to someone who was going through a crisis. I myself have reported a mental health crisis due to OHS concerns relating to self-harm in the past and been told to "keep all of this to yourself, or your career will be over." and "I don't want you talking to anyone else about your problem and distracting them." I was then told that "since I can't fire you due to mental health reasons, I want you to avoid talking to anyone and see out the end of your contract, which won't be renewed". I felt unsupported by the institution and was afraid of reprisals if I made this known as there was no way to "prove" what was said to me. I had to leave my career as a result. However, at another institution my managers and senior managers have been supportive understanding and accommodating. However, there is no way to predict how someone will react to a disclosure and so there is hesitation about disclosing declining mental health due to this "chilling effect".

While mental health is both serious and challenging to address in any setting, academia is far more forgiving than the military or nearly any part of the private sector. I wonder if there is a selection effect or extreme sense of privilege driving mental health concerns in academia or perhaps a diagnostic bias that is just more sensitive now versus other generations. I find the fact that some of my peers expect to earn a very comfortable living turning large volumes of tax dollars into relatively inane research topic investigations with little accountability deeply concerning and perhaps they should be stressed in this world view. That said we should all have the right to work in a safe environment. I just can't help but wonder if unrealistic expectations drive some mental health issues.

When you're in the middle of a mental health crisis, simple things are hard. When one of your identities is being attacked in every sphere of your life, and your institution fails to adequately respond to the issues you bring to them, you can feel incredibly isolated and unsupported, and not have the energy or trust in the system to make use of what resources you do have. Or you may have access to some resources in theory but not practically, such as when you're directed to a particular office or advocate who fails to help you, or when using a resource involves hours of phonecalls you can't bring yourself to make, or when the resource you track down turns you away. I have experienced all of these and have learned to cut my losses earlier and give and seek support within a smaller community when my institution inevitably fails me.
